chapter.title: Configuring and Managing Cluster Resources with &hawk2;

abstract.para: To configure and manage cluster resources, either use &haweb; (&hawk2;), or the &crmshell; (&crmsh;) command line utility. If you upgrade from an earlier version of &productnamereg; where &hawk; was installed, the package will be replaced with the current version, &hawk2;.

&hawk2;'s Web-based user-interface allows you to monitor and administer your Linux cluster from non-Linux machines. Furthermore, it is the ideal solution in case your system only provides a minimal graphical user interface.

sect1.title: &hawk2; Requirements
sect1.para: Before users can log in to &hawk2;, the following requirements need to be fulfilled:

listitem.para: The hawk2 package must be installed on all cluster nodes you want to connect to with &hawk2;.
On the machine from which you want to access a cluster node using &hawk2;, you only need a (graphical) Web browser with JavaScript and cookies enabled to establish the connection.
To use &hawk2;, the respective Web service must be started on the node that you want to connect to via the Web interface. See .
If you have set up your cluster with the scripts from the ha-cluster-bootstrap package, the &hawk2; service is already enabled.

&hawk2; users must be members of the haclient group. The installation creates a Linux user named hacluster, who is added to the haclient group. When using the ha-cluster-init script for setup, a default password is set for the hacluster user.
Before starting &hawk2;, set or change the password for the hacluster user. Alternatively, create a new user which is a member of the haclient group.
Do this on every node you will connect to with &hawk2;.

sect1.title: Logging In
sect1.para: The &hawk2; Web interface uses the HTTPS protocol and port 7630.

Instead of logging in to an individual cluster node with &hawk2;, you can configure a floating, virtual IP address (IPaddr or IPaddr2) as a cluster resource. It does not need any special configuration. It allows clients to connect to the &hawk; service no matter which physical node the service is running on.
When setting up the cluster with the ha-cluster-bootstrap scripts, you will be asked whether to configure a virtual IP for cluster administration.

procedure.title: Logging In to the &hawk2; Web Interface

step.para: On any machine, start a Web browser and make sure that JavaScript and cookies are enabled.

note.title: Certificate Warning
note.para: If a certificate warning appears when you try to access the URL for the first time, a self-signed certificate is in use. Self-signed certificates are not considered trustworthy by default.
To verify the certificate, ask your cluster operator for the certificate details.
To proceed anyway, you can add an exception in the browser to bypass the warning.
For information on how to replace the self-signed certificate with a certificate signed by an official Certificate Authority, refer to .

step.para: On the &hawk2; login screen, enter the Username and Password of the hacluster user (or of any other user that is a member of the haclient group).
Click Log In.

sect1.title: &hawk2; Overview: Main Elements
sect1.para: After logging in to &hawk2;, you will see a navigation bar on the left-hand side and a top-level row with several links on the right-hand side.

note.title: Available Functions in &hawk2;
note.para: By default, users logged in as &rootuser; or hacluster have full read-write access to all cluster configuration tasks. However, (ACLs) can be used to define fine-grained access permissions.

If ACLs are enabled in the CRM, the available functions in &hawk2; depend on the user role and their assigned access permissions. In addition, the following function in &hawk2; can only be executed by the user hacluster: Using the History Explorer.

listitem.para: Status: Displays the current cluster status at a glance (similar to crm status on the &crmsh;). For details, see . The screen refreshes in near real-time: any status changes for nodes or resources are visible almost immediately.

Dashboard: Allows you to monitor multiple clusters (also located on different sites, in case you have a &geo; cluster setup). For details, see . The screen refreshes in near real-time: any status changes for nodes or resources are visible almost immediately.
History: Opens the History Explorer from which you can generate cluster reports. For details, see .
Add resource: Opens the resource configuration screen. For details, see .
Add constraint: Opens the constraint configuration screen. For details, see .
Wizard: Allows you to select from several wizards that guide you through the creation of resources for a certain workload, for example, a DRBD block device. For details, see .
Edit Configuration: Allows you to edit node names and attributes, resources, constraints, and tags.
Cluster Configuration: Allows you to modify global cluster options and resource and operation defaults. For details, see .
Command Log: Lists the &crmsh; commands recently executed by &hawk2;.
Roles: Opens a screen where you can create roles for access control lists (sets of rules describing access rights to the CIB).
Targets: Opens a screen where you can create targets (system users) for access control lists and assign roles to them.

sect1.title: Configuring Global Cluster Options
sect1.para: Global cluster options control how the cluster behaves when confronted with certain situations. They are grouped into sets and can be viewed and modified with cluster management tools like &hawk2; and &crmsh;. The predefined values can usually be kept. However, to ensure the key functions of your cluster work correctly, you need to adjust the following parameters after basic cluster setup:

step.para: Log in to &hawk2;:
From the left navigation bar, select Cluster Configuration.
The Cluster Configuration screen opens. It displays the global cluster options and their current values.
To display a short description of the parameter on the right-hand side of the screen, hover your mouse over a parameter.
Check the values for no-quorum-policy and stonith-enabled and adjust them, if necessary:
Set no-quorum-policy to the appropriate value. See for more details.

substeps.step: If you need to disable fencing for any reason, set stonith-enabled to no. By default, it is set to true, because for normal cluster operation it is necessary to use &stonith; devices. According to the default value, the cluster will refuse to start any resources if no &stonith; resources have been configured. &important-stonith;

step.para: To remove a parameter from the cluster configuration, click the Minus icon next to the parameter. If a parameter is deleted, the cluster will behave as if that parameter had the default value.
To add a new parameter to the cluster configuration, choose one from the drop-down box and click the Plus icon.
If you need to change Resource Defaults or Operation Defaults, proceed as follows:
To adjust a value, either select a different value from the drop-down box or edit the value directly.
To add a new resource default or operation default, choose one from the empty drop-down box, click the Plus icon and enter a value. If there are default values, &hawk2; proposes them automatically.
To remove a parameter, click the Minus icon next to it. If no values are specified for Resource Defaults and Operation Defaults, the cluster uses the default values that are documented in and .
Confirm your changes.
